Allergen / Source: Wool
Less Common Symptoms / Notes: Hives, burning sensation, swelling (especially in those with atopic dermatitis or sensitive skin)

Allergen / Source: Polyester, Nylon, Rayon, Spandex, Rubber (synthetic fibers)
Common Symptoms: Itching, redness, rash, discomfort due to poor breathability and sweating
Less Common Symptoms / Notes: Blisters, burning sensation, allergic contact dermatitis (especially after prolonged exposure or sweating)

Allergen / Source: Synthetic Dyes (dark/vibrant colors)
Common Symptoms: Redness, itching, rash, swelling at contact points
Less Common Symptoms / Notes: Blisters, hives, burning sensation; reactions may occur after repeated exposure or with high dye content

Allergen / Source: Formaldehyde Resins (wrinkle-free, dirt-repellent, permanent press finishes)
Less Common Symptoms / Notes: Allergic contact dermatitis, blisters, burning sensation

Allergen / Source: Other Chemicals (glues, tanning agents for leather, finishing resins)
Nickel (buttons, zippers, fasteners)
Common Symptoms: Red, itchy rash at contact site (nickel dermatitis)
Less Common Symptoms / Notes: Blisters, swelling, chronic irritation if exposure continues

Allergen / Source: Latex (elastic bands, gloves)
Less Common Symptoms / Notes: Hives, blisters, respiratory symptoms (rare in clothing, more common with medical gloves)

Allergen / Source: Detailed Symptom Descriptions:
Itching: Persistent urge to scratch, often with redness.
Redness: Inflamed skin, sometimes visibly irritated.
Rash: Raised, bumpy, or scaly patches, may spread beyond contact area.
Hives: Swollen, pale red bumps or plaques that appear suddenly.
Blisters: Small fluid-filled bumps, often indicate severe reaction.
Burning Sensation: Skin feels hot or stinging, sometimes visibly inflamed.
Swelling: Puffiness or enlargement of skin at contact site.
Contact Dermatitis: Combination of redness, itching, rash, sometimes blisters, usually localized.
Additional Notes:
People with sensitive skin, atopic dermatitis, or allergies are at higher risk.
Symptoms may appear immediately or after prolonged exposure.
Some allergens (dyes, chemicals) may be present in higher concentrations in new or unwashed garments.
